message_1: A 2-level quantum system can be represented by a qubit. Suppose you have a qubit which is in an unknown state. You want to know what the state is, but you can only perform measurements in the computational basis. Design a procedure to obtain a complete description of the qubit state using quantum state tomography.
message_2:
To perform quantum state tomography on a qubit in an unknown state, we need to reconstruct the density matrix of the qubit. A general qubit state can be represented as:

|ψ⟩ = α|0⟩ + β|1⟩

where α and β are complex numbers, and |α|^2 + |β|^2 = 1. The density matrix ρ for this state is given by:

ρ = |ψ⟩⟨ψ| = (|α|^2    αβ*)
          (βα*    |β|^2)

Since we can only perform measurements in the computational basis, we will need to rotate the qubit state to access the off-diagonal elements of the density matrix. We can do this using the following procedure:

1. Measure the qubit in the computational basis (|0⟩ and |1⟩) to obtain the probabilities P(0) and P(1). These probabilities correspond to the diagonal elements of the density matrix:

   P(0) = |α|^2
   P(1) = |β|^2

2. Apply a Hadamard gate (H) to the qubit, which rotates the basis states:

   H|0⟩ = (|0⟩ + |1⟩)/√2
   H|1⟩ = (|0⟩ - |1⟩)/√2

3. Measure the qubit in the new basis (H|0⟩ and H|1⟩) to obtain the probabilities P(H0) and P(H1):

   P(H0) = |⟨H0|ψ⟩|^2 = |(α + β)/√2|^2
   P(H1) = |⟨H1|ψ⟩|^2 = |(α - β)/√2|^2

4. Calculate the real part of the off-diagonal element of the density matrix:

   Re(αβ*) = (P(H0) - P(H1))/2

5. Apply a phase gate (S†) to the qubit:

   S†|0⟩ = |0⟩
   S†|1⟩ = -i|1⟩

6. Apply a Hadamard gate (H) to the qubit again and measure the probabilities P(H0') and P(H1'):

   P(H0') = |⟨H0|S†ψ⟩|^2 = |(α - iβ)/√2|^2
   P(H1') = |⟨H1|S†ψ⟩|^2 = |(α + iβ)/√2|^2

7. Calculate the imaginary part of the off-diagonal element of the density matrix:

   Im(αβ*) = (P(H0') - P(H1'))/2

Now, we have all the elements required to reconstruct the density matrix:

ρ = (|α|^2    Re(αβ*) + i*Im(αβ*))
          (Re(αβ*) - i*Im(αβ*)    |β|^2)

By following this procedure, we can obtain a complete description of the qubit state using quantum state tomography with measurements in the computational basis.
